description: From Middle English pees, pes, pais, borrowed from Anglo-Norman peis and Old French pais (“peace”), from Latin pāx (“peace”), from Proto-Indo-European *peh₂ḱ- (“to fasten, stick, place”), related to Latin pacīscor (“agree, stipulate”), Latin pangō (“fasten, fix”); see pact. Displaced native Old English sibb and friþ.

entries.meaning: A state of tranquility, quiet, and harmony; absence of violence. For instance, a state free from civil disturbance.
A state free of oppressive and unpleasant thoughts and emotions.
examples: The safety equipment will give me some peace of mind.

entries.meaning: A state free of war, in particular war between different countries.

verbs.description: peace (third-person singular simple present peaces, present participle peacing, simple past and past participle peaced)

entries.meaning: To make peace; to put at peace; to be at peace.
examples: Within every hood they have to be peacing with themselves. Then when you're living in peace with yourself, [...]
